I agree that impoverished seniors should get an SS augmentation. And I also agree that children in poverty deserve a hand, from prenatal nutrition through pre-K education and on. It is astounding that 43% of black children live below the poverty line in this country, and I'm sure that the percentage of white and Hispanic children is no less acceptable. And I'd bet that the percentage of Native American children is worse.

The phenomenon of so many children living in poverty is not only a moral outrage and tragedy, it's the seed of greater societal problems in the future. Can our leaders not see that assisting these children through their growth to adulthood and productive, positive citizenship will be less of a burden than not assisting them?

And, in addition, there needs to be a greater focus on job production for these children, and everyone. The actions of our Congress have been counter to job production, with government spending at a record low as a percentage of GDP, the inadequate stimulus, the sequester, the shutdown, etc. All of these have been solid blows to economic growth and job production, and all of them sacrificial offerings to the gods of austerity and class warfare.

Am I wrong in fearing that there's a subconscious, at least, motive of repression in failing to address these human needs properly?

For many years I assigned history students the task of writing a paper comparing the Gettysburg address with Pericles oration. Great history, great literature.

I highly recommend Gary Wills' Pulitzer prize winning "Lincoln at Gettysburg" in which he shows Lincoln to be, among other things, a great student of history.

Wills points out how Lincoln in constructing his masterpiece followed a template for a state funeral oration laid down in the 4th century bc by Pericles, stating, for example, why it is proper that they observe this occasion and why this is hallowed ground. By paying respect to all who fought in this battle and not distinguishing between fallen soldiers from one side or the other, like Pericles, Lincoln amplified the loss of life and gave the moment added solemnity.

Wills also argues that by giving the Declaration of Independence primacy over the Constitution and the Bill of Rights, Lincoln gave the North a powerful transcendent cause which, up to that point, had been lacking in its struggle to preserve the union.

"I want to put in a bid for providing sufficient payments to cover the cost of living for people who have to pay for living in apartments designed for those who must be assisted as they adjust to the ravages of age."

A system like this already exists in Germany, where we now have "nursing care insurance." This system, which was established in 1995, provides a monthly payment to people who need nursing assistance. The amount paid depends on the level of care needed. It can be used to pay for professional nursing care/assisted living services -- or to compensate family members and others who provide care voluntarily (and who may have given up their jobs or reduced their working hours in order to do so). The cost of the program is an additional 1.05% deduction for workers and 1.05% for employers (up to a certain income cap).

In the end, a system like this actually saves money, since it enables people to stay in their homes, which is a lot cheaper than the cost of care at a nursing home. Even more importantly, by allowing older people to stay in their familiar surroundings, it greatly adds to their quality of life.

Of course, I wouldn't hold out much hope of ever implementing something like that in the U.S.--it would be much too "socialist"!
